summary: This is a First Amended Complaint filed by the Government of the United States Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein, its executors, and associated corporate entities. The complaint alleges that Epstein and his 'Epstein Enterprise' used a complex network of Virgin Islands corporations and properties to facilitate and conceal a pattern of sex trafficking, sexual abuse, and forced labor of young women and underage girls on his private islands, Little St. James and Great St. James. The GVI seeks damages and enforcement of local laws. This document is a portion of the First Amended Complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein. It details the operations of the 'Epstein Enterprise,' focusing on its use of private islands (Little St. James and Great St. James) for sex trafficking and abuse, fraudulent concealment of activities, violation of environmental and corporate laws, and the use of corporate entities to secure tax benefits and fund criminal activities. This document is a portion of the First Amended Complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein. It details Counts Three through Fourteen, which allege violations of the Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO) related to human trafficking, forced labor, sexual servitude, child abuse, and rape. The complaint describes the 'Epstein Enterprise' as an illicit organization and accuses the defendants of conspiring with Epstein to commit these crimes. This document is a portion of the First Amended Complaint filed by the Government of the Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein and other defendants. It details multiple counts under the Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organization Act (CICO), alleging a pattern of criminal activity including human trafficking, forced labor, sexual servitude, prostitution, sex offender registry violations, fraudulent conveyance, and fraudulent claims upon the government. The complaint describes the 'Epstein Enterprise' as an illicit organization that used properties and entities to facilitate and conceal crimes. This is a First Amended Complaint filed by the Government of the United States Virgin Islands (GVI) against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein and the 'Epstein Enterprise'. It alleges a pattern of criminal activity including human trafficking, forced labor, and sexual abuse of minors in the Virgin Islands. The document serves notice of the government's intent to seek punitive damages and requests extensive relief, including forfeiture of property, dissolution of the enterprise, and financial penalties.

connections.description: Indyke served as co-executor of Epstein's estate and held officer positions (secretary/director) in multiple Epstein-controlled Virgin Islands corporations.
Kahn served as co-executor of Epstein's estate and held officer positions (treasurer/director) in multiple Epstein-controlled Virgin Islands corporations.
Visoski was Epstein's pilot and was listed as the manager/member of corporate entities (Plan D, LLC, Hyperion Air, LLC) that owned aircraft used by Epstein.
Both served as co-executors of Epstein's Estate and co-administrators of The 1953 Trust, and held complementary officer roles in the same corporate entities.
Epstein employed Visoski as his pilot, and Visoski was listed as a member in companies that held assets for and serviced Epstein's planes used in trafficking.
Kellerhals acted as Epstein's attorney, providing testimony to a government commission on behalf of his company, Southern Trust Company.
George, as Attorney General, is the lead government attorney prosecuting the civil case against Epstein's estate.
Both are listed as contact attorneys for the Virgin Islands Department of Justice in this filing.

events.title: Epstein acquires Little St. James
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein acquired the private island of Little St. James in the Virgin Islands, which later became a primary location for alleged sexual abuse and trafficking.

events.title: Epstein registers as sex offender in Virgin Islands
events.description: Epstein registered as a Tier 1 sex offender in the Virgin Islands following his Florida conviction for procuring a minor for prostitution.

events.title: Epstein purchases Great St. James
events.description: Epstein purchased the neighboring island of Great St. James, allegedly to further shield his criminal activities on Little St. James from detection.

events.title: Epstein found dead in custody
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead while in custody in New York on federal sex trafficking charges.

events.title: Estate files probate petition
events.description: Defendants Indyke and Kahn filed a Petition for Probate and Letters Testamentary for Epstein's Estate in the Virgin Islands Superior Court.

events.title: Acquisition of Little St. James
events.description: The Epstein Enterprise acquired Little St. James island in the Virgin Islands, described as a secluded hideaway used for trafficking and sexual abuse.

events.title: Acquisition of Great St. James
events.description: The Epstein Enterprise, allegedly using a straw purchaser, acquired Great St. James island for over $20 million to prevent observation of activities on Little St. James and create barriers to escape.

events.title: Sex Offender Registration Verification
events.description: Epstein refused to allow Virgin Islands Department of Justice Investigators and U.S. Marshals to enter Little St. James beyond the dock for a sex offender address verification, meeting them at his St. Thomas office instead.

events.title: Misleading Travel Notification
events.description: Epstein notified the Virgin Islands of travel to France but was later found by law enforcement to have also traveled to Vienna and Monaco during the same trip.

events.title: Estate Files Motion for Claims Program
events.description: Epstein's Estate filed an Expedited Motion to establish a voluntary claims resolution program for sexual abuse claims, which included confidentiality requirements and waiver of other claims.

events.title: Asset Transfer to The 1953 Trust
events.description: Days before his death, Epstein allegedly transferred significant assets into 'The 1953 Trust' in an effort to defeat creditor claims and avoid probate court oversight.

events.title: Undisclosed Travel to Vienna and Monaco
events.description: Epstein traveled to Vienna and Monaco on at least two occasions without disclosing the travel to the Virgin Islands sex offender registry as required by law.

events.title: Filing of First Amended Complaint
events.description: The Government of the Virgin Islands files its First Amended Complaint against the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein, formally alleging a pattern of criminal activity and seeking extensive civil remedies.

events.title: Notice of Intent to Seek Punitive Damages
events.description: The government gives formal notice within the complaint that it intends to pursue punitive damages against the defendants, citing their alleged intentional, outrageous, and reckless conduct.

keyFacts: The Government of the Virgin Islands alleges Epstein used a complex web of local corporations (Nautilus, Inc., Great St. Jim, LLC, Poplar, Inc., Plan D, LLC, Hyperion Air, LLC, Southern Trust Company) to own properties and aircraft that facilitated and concealed his sex trafficking operation.

Epstein's Estate, valued at over $577 million in Virgin Islands assets, and The 1953 Trust, amended two days before his death, are named as defendants responsible for paying damages for his alleged crimes.
The complaint details specific allegations of abuse on Little St. James, including a 15-year-old victim attempting to escape by swimming and having her passport confiscated.
Epstein's aircraft, owned by Plan D, LLC and Hyperion Air, LLC, were allegedly used to transport underage girls and young women to the Virgin Islands for sexual exploitation between 2001 and 2019.
Epstein was a registered Tier 1 sex offender in the Virgin Islands and was required to notify authorities of his travel to and from the territory.

The 'Epstein Enterprise' used the secluded private islands of Little St. James (acquired 1998) and Great St. James (acquired 2016) to traffic, sexually abuse, and hold women and children, preventing escape due to the islands' isolation.

Epstein and his enterprise created numerous Virgin Islands corporate entities (e.g., Southern Trust Company) to conceal assets, fund criminal activities, and fraudulently obtain significant tax exemptions totaling tens of millions of dollars.

The enterprise systematically concealed its activities by preventing employee cooperation with law enforcement through confidentiality agreements, obstructing government inspections, and misleading authorities about travel.
Epstein's pilot, Larry Visoski, was tied to companies that held assets for and serviced the planes used to traffic victims.

The complaint alleges the enterprise violated multiple Virgin Islands laws, including human trafficking, child abuse, and environmental statutes, and seeks civil penalties, damages, and forfeiture of properties used in the crimes.
The complaint formally defines and accuses the 'Epstein Enterprise' of being an illicit criminal organization under the Virgin Islands' Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (CICO).
Specific criminal acts alleged include human trafficking for forced labor and sexual servitude, child abuse and neglect, aggravated rape, and second-degree rape.

The complaint details a method of operation where young women and underage girls were allegedly lured to the Virgin Islands with promises of modeling opportunities, careers, scholarships, or gifts in exchange for sexual acts with Epstein and others.
All defendants are accused of conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein and each other to fulfill the primary criminal purposes of the enterprise: human trafficking, forced labor, and sexual servitude.

The complaint frames Epstein's activities as an 'Enterprise' under the Virgin Islands' Criminally Influenced and Corrupt Organization Act (CICO), alleging a pattern of criminal activity including human trafficking, forced labor, and sexual servitude.

Epstein's property on Little St. James is alleged to have been used as a location for prostitution, lewdness, and the sexual abuse of minors, with the Enterprise facilitating travel to the island for these purposes.
Days before his death, Epstein allegedly engaged in a fraudulent conveyance by transferring significant assets into 'The 1953 Trust' to hinder creditors and avoid probate court jurisdiction.
Epstein violated the Virgin Islands Sex Offender Registration Act by failing to disclose international travel to Vienna and Monaco.

The Epstein Enterprise is accused of making fraudulent claims to the government by misrepresenting the purpose and activities of the Southern Trust Company, Inc. to obtain and maintain valuable tax incentives that funded criminal activities.

The Government of the Virgin Islands alleges the 'Epstein Enterprise' engaged in a pattern of criminal activity in the territory including human trafficking, forced labor, sexual servitude of female children and young women, rape, and prostitution.

The government seeks forfeiture of all Epstein's interests in Virgin Islands real and personal property, specifically naming Little St. James Island and Greater St. James Island as properties used to facilitate the criminal enterprise.
The complaint seeks the dissolution of the 'Epstein Enterprise' and the revocation of any licenses, permits, and tax benefits granted to the defendants by the territory.
The government gives formal notice of its intent to seek punitive damages, arguing the defendants' conduct was so egregious that mere economic damages are insufficient.
The filing requests the court to void the transfer of assets to 'The 1953 Trust' as fraudulently conveyed.
